0.desc: Frozen world. No liquid water, very dry atmosphere.

1.desc: Icy world. Little liquid water, extensive ice caps, few clouds.

2.desc: Temperate world. Earth-like. Liquid & vaporised water are common, moderate ice caps.

3.desc: Hot world. Small or no ice caps, little liquid water. Most water in the form of clouds.

4.desc: Boiling world. No more ice caps, little liquid water.

9.desc: Only a few small islands and archipelagos

1.desc: A tiny farmstead or a single family

0.desc: No government structure. In many cases,family bonds predominate

1.desc: Ruling functions are assumed by a company managerial elite, and most citizenry are company employees or dependants
1.ex: Corporate outpost, asteroid mine, feudal domain

2.desc: Ruling functions are reached by the advice and consent of the citizenry directly

3.desc: Ruling functions are performed by a restricted minority, with little or no input from the mass of citizenry

4.desc: Ruling functions are performed by elected, representatives

5.desc: Ruling functions are performed by specific individuals for persons who agree to be ruled by them. Relationships are based on the performance of technical activities  which are mutually beneficial
5.ex: Those with access to higher technology tend to have higher social status

6.desc: Ruling functions are performed by an imposed leadership answerable to an outside group

7.desc: No central authority exists; rival governments complete for control. Law level refers to the government nearest the starport

8.desc: Ruling functions are performed by government agencies employing individuals selected for their expertise

9.desc: Ruling functions are performed by agencies which have become insulated from the governed citizens
9.ex: Entrenched castes of bureaucrats, decaying empire

A.desc: Ruling functions are performed by agencies directed by a single leader who enjoys the overwhelming confidence of the citizens

B.desc: A previous charismatic dictator has been replaced by a leader through normal channels

C.desc: Ruling functions are performed by a select group of members of an organisation or class which enjoys the overwhelming confidence of the citizenry

D.desc: Ruling functions are performed by a religious organisation without regard to the specific individual needs of the citizenry
D.ex: Cult, transcendent philosophy, psionic group mind

E.desc: Government by a single religious leader having absolute power over the citizenry

F.desc: Government by an all-powerful minority which maintains absolute control through widespread coercion and oppresion

0.desc: few have heard of them, no popular support

11.name: Sexist
11.desc: one gender is considered subservient or inferior to the other.

12.name: Religious
12.desc: culture is heavily influenced by a religion or belief systems, possibly one unique to this world.

13.name: Artistic
13.desc: art and culture are highly prized. Aesthetic design is important in all artefacts produced on world.

14.name: Ritualised
14.desc: social interaction and trade is highly formalised. Politeness and adherence to traditional forms is considered very important.

15.name: Conservative
15.desc: the culture resists change and outside influences.

16.name: Xenophobic
16.desc: the culture distrusts outsiders and alien influences. Offworlders will face considerable prejudice.

21.name: Taboo
21.desc: a particular topic is forbidden and cannot be discussed. Travellers who unwittingly mention this topic will be ostracised.

22.name: Deceptive
22.desc: trickery and equivocation are considered acceptable. Honesty is a sign of weakness.

23.name: Liberal
23.desc: the culture welcomes change and offworld influence. Travellers who bring new and strange ideas will be welcomed.

24.name: Honourable
24.desc: one’s word is one’s bond in the culture. Lying is both rare and despised.

25.name: Influenced
25.desc: the culture is heavily influenced by another, neighbouring world. Roll again for a cultural quirk that has been inherited from the culture.

26.name: Fusion
26.desc: the culture is a merger of two distinct cultures. Roll again twice to determine the quirks inherited from these cultures. If the quirks are incompatible, then the culture is likely divided.

31.name: Barbaric
31.desc: physical strength and combat prowess are highly valued in the culture. Travellers may be challenged to a fight, or dismissed if they seem incapable of defending themselves. Sports tend towards the bloody and violent.

32.name: Remnant
32.desc: the culture is a surviving remnant of a once-great and vibrant civilisation, clinging to its former glory. The world is filled with crumbling ruins, and every story revolves around the good old days.

33.name: Degenerate
33.desc: the culture is falling apart and is on the brink of war or economic collapse. Violent protests are common, and the social order is decaying.

34.name: Progressive
34.desc: the culture is expanding and vibrant. Fortunes are being made in trade; science is forging bravely ahead.

35.name: Recovering
35.desc: a recent trauma, such as a plague, war, disaster or despotic regime has left scars on the culture.

36.name: Nexus
36.desc: members of many different cultures and species visit here.

41.name: Tourist Attraction
41.desc: some aspect of the culture or the planet draws visitors from all over charted space.

42.name: Violent
42.desc: physical conflict is common, taking the form of duels, brawls or other contests. Trial by combat is a part of their judicial system.

43.name: Peaceful
43.desc: physical conflict is almost unheard-of. The culture produces few soldiers, and diplomacy reigns supreme. Forceful Travellers will be ostracised.

44.name: Obsessed
44.desc: everyone is obsessed with or addicted to a substance, personality, act or item. This monomania pervades every aspect of the culture.

45.name: Fashion
45.desc: fine clothing and decoration are considered vitally important in the culture. Underdressed Travellers have no standing here.

46.name: At war
46.desc: the culture is at war, either with another planet or polity, or is troubled by terrorists or rebels.

51.name: Unusual Custom: Offworlders
51.desc: space travellers hold a unique position in the culture’s mythology or beliefs, and travellers will be expected to live up to these myths.

52.name: Unusual Custom: Starport
52.desc: the planet’s starport is more than a commercial centre; it might be a religious temple, or be seen as highly controversial and surrounded by protestors.

53.name: Unusual Custom: Media
53.desc: news agencies and telecommunications channels are especially strange here. Getting accurate information may be difficult.

54.name: Unusual Customs: Technology
54.desc: the culture interacts with technology in an unusual way. Telecommunications might be banned, robots might have civil rights, or cyborgs might be property.

55.name: Unusual Customs: Lifecycle
55.desc: there might be a mandatory age of termination, or anagathics might be widely used. Family units might be different, with children being raised by the state or banned in favour of cloning.

56.name: Unusual Customs: Social Standings
56.desc: the culture has a distinct caste system. Travellers of a low social standing who do not behave appropriately will face punishment.

61.name: Unusual Customs: Trade
61.desc: the culture has an odd attitude towards some aspect of commerce, which may interfere with trade at the spaceport. For example, merchants might expect a gift as part of a deal, or some goods may only be handled by certain families.

62.name: Unusual Customs: Nobility
62.desc: those of high social standing have a strange custom associated with them; perhaps nobles are blinded, or must live in gilded cages, or only serve for a single year before being exiled.

63.name: Unusual Customs: Sex
63.desc: he culture has an unusual attitude towards intercourse and reproduction. Perhaps cloning is used instead, or sex is used to seal commercial deals.

64.name: Unusual Customs: Eating
64.desc: food and drink occupies an unusual place in the culture. Perhaps eating is a private affair, or banquets and formal dinners are seen as the highest form of politeness.

65.name: Unusual Customs: Travel
65.desc: travellers may be distrusted or feted, or perhaps the culture frowns on those who leave their homes.

66.name: Unusual Custom: Conspiracy
66.desc: something strange is going on. The government is being subverted by another group or agency.

0.weapons: No restrictions – heavy armour and a handy weapon recommended...

1.weapons: Poison gas, explosives, undetectable weapons, WMD

2.weapons: Portable energy and laser Combat armour weapons

4.weapons: Light assault weapons and submachine guns

6.weapons: All firearms except shotguns & stunners; carrying weapons discouraged

0.desc: No technology. TL 0 species have only discovered the simplest tools and principles, and are on a par with Earth’s Stone Age.

1.desc: Roughly on a par with Bronze or Iron age technology. TL 1 science is mostly superstition, but they can manufacture weapons and work metals.

2.desc: Renaissance technology. TL 2 brings with it a greater understanding of chemistry, physics, biology and astronomy as well as the scientific method.

3.desc: The advances of TL 2 are now applied, bringing the germ of industrial revolution and steam power. Primitive firearms now dominate the battlefield. This is roughly comparable to the early 19th century.

4.desc: The transition to industrial revolution is complete, bringing plastics, radio and other such inventions. Roughly comparable to the late 19th/early 20th century.

5.desc: TL 5 brings widespread electrification, tele-communications and internal combustion. At the high end of the TL, atomics and primitive computing appear. Roughly on a par with the mid–20th century.

6.desc: TL 6 brings the development of fission power and more advanced computing. Advances in materials technology and rocketry bring about the dawn of the space age.

7.desc: A pre-stellar society can reach orbit reliably and has telecommunications satellites. Computers become common. At the time of writing, humanity is currently somewhere between TL 7 and TL 8.

8.desc: At TL 8, it is possible to reach other worlds in the same system, although terraforming or full colonisation are not within the culture’s capacity. Permanent space habitats become possible. Fusion power becomes commercially viable.

9.desc: The defining element of TL 9 is the development of gravity manipulation, which makes space travel vastly safer and faster. This research leads to development of the jump drive, which occurs near the end of this Tech Level. TL 9 cultures can colonise other worlds, although travelling to a colony is often a one-way trip.

A.desc: With the advent of commonly available jump drives, nearby systems are opened up. Orbital habitats and factories become common. Interstellar travel and trade lead to an economic boom. Colonies become much more viable.

B.desc: The first true artificial intelligences become possible, as computers are able to model synaptic networks. Grav-supported structures reach to the heavens. Jump 2 travel becomes possible, allowing easier travel beyond the one jump stellar mains.

C.desc: Weather control revolutionises terraforming and agriculture. Man-portable plasma weapons and carrier-mounted fusion guns make the battlefield untenable for unarmoured combatants. Jump 3 travel is developed.

D.desc: The battle dress appears on the battlefield in response to the new weapons. Cloning of body parts becomes easy. Advances in hull design and thruster plates means that spacecraft can easily go underwater. Jump 4 travel.

E.desc: Fusion weapons become man-portable. Flying cities appear. Jump 5 travel.

F.desc: Black globe generators suggest a new direction for defensive technologies, while the development of synthetic anagathics means that the human lifespan is now vastly increased. Jump 6 travel.

Ag.name: Agricultural
Ag.desc: Dedicated to farming and food production. Often, they are divided into vast semi-feudal estates.

As.name: Asteroid
As.desc: Usually mining colonies, but can also be orbital factories or colonies.

Fl.name: Fluid Oceans
Fl.desc: Worlds where the surface liquid is something other than water, and so are incompatible with Earth-derived life.

Ht.name: High tech
Ht.desc: Among the most technologically advanced in Charted Space.

Ic.name: Ice-Capped
Ic.desc: Worlds that have most of their surface liquid frozen in polar ice caps, and are cold and dry.

Lo.name: Low Population
Lo.desc: A population of only a few thousand or less.

Lt.name: Low Tech
Lt.desc: Pre-industrial and cannot produce advanced goods.

Na.name: Non-Agricultural
Na.desc: Too dry or barren to support their populations using conventional food production.

NI.name: Non-Industrial
NI.desc: Too low in population to maintain an extensive industrial base.

Po.name: Poor
Po.desc: Lacking resources, viable land or sufficient population to be anything other than marginal colonies.

Ri.name: Rich
Ri.desc: Blessed with a stable government and viable biosphere, making them economic powerhouses.

Wa.name: Water World
Wa.desc: Almost entirely water-ocean across their surface.
